body_html:
Awesome, thanks. tf.substring_match would check to see if a selected subsection of a string (or array of strings), s1, matches another passed in string, s2. It would return true if the substring matches, false otherwise. You can think of tf.startswith as a special case of tf.substring_match, where the selected subsection is at the beginning of s1.

Proposed api:

Args:
  s1: Tensor of type `string`. The strings that will have a substring compared against `s2`
  s2: 0-D Tensor of type `string`. The string that the `s1` substring(s) will be compared against
  start_idx: 0-D integer. The starting index of the substring in `s1`

It would return true if the substring matches, false otherwise. You can think of tf.startswith as a special case of tf.substring_match, where the selected subsection is at the beginning of s1.
Proposed api:
Args:
  s1: Tensor of type `string`. The strings that will have a substring compared against `s2`
  s2: 0-D Tensor of type `string`. The string that the `s1` substring(s) will be compared against
  start_idx: 0-D integer. The starting index of the substring in `s1`
body:
Awesome, thanks. `tf.substring_match` would check to see if a selected subsection of a string (or array of strings), `s1`, matches another passed in string, `s2`. It would return true if the substring matches, false otherwise. You can think of `tf.startswith` as a special case of `tf.substring_match`, where the selected subsection is at the beginning of `s1`. 

Proposed api:

```
Args:
  s1: Tensor of type `string`. The strings that will have a substring compared against `s2`
  s2: 0-D Tensor of type `string`. The string that the `s1` substring(s) will be compared against
  start_idx: 0-D integer. The starting index of the substring in `s1` 
```
